pcbComponents.title: PCB Components
pcbComponents.tagline: The building blocks of your circuit board
pcbComponents.description: These are the electronic components that make up your keyboard's circuit board. Whether you're building a custom PCB or handwiring, you'll need diodes, resistors, connectors, and other components. Your choice between SMD (surface-mount) and through-hole components affects build difficulty, PCB size, and professional appearance.
whyItMatters: SMD vs through-hole determines build difficulty and required soldering skills
Connector choice (TRRS/TRS, USB-C) affects durability and compatibility
Optional components (buttons, speakers, power switches) add functionality
Protection components (capacitors, ESD diodes) improve reliability

keyTradeoffs.description: Through-hole components are easier to solder and more beginner-friendly, but take more PCB space. SMD components are tiny, professional-looking, and compact, but require fine-pitch soldering skills, tweezers, and good lighting.

TRRS jacks are standard for split keyboards ($1 for jacks + cable), reliable but can short if hot-plugged. USB-C is modern and durable but requires precise PCB design and 5.1kΩ resistors. TRS is simpler but only supports serial communication.

Diodes are mandatory (one per switch). Resistors needed for LEDs and I2C. Reset buttons are highly recommended. Capacitors and ESD protection are optional but improve stability. Speakers/buzzers are rare but fun.
Wireless builds require power switches ($0.30), battery connectors ($0.20), and careful power routing. Wired builds skip these entirely. Battery protection circuits add safety but complexity.

quickTips: Start with through-hole components for your first build - much easier to solder
SMD diodes (SOD-123) and resistors (0805/1206) are manageable with practice and flux
Always use TRRS (4-conductor) cables, not TRS, to avoid damaging your keyboard
USB-C connectors MUST have 5.1kΩ pull-down resistors on CC pins to work properly
Add 0.1µF capacitors near every IC power pin for stability
Reset buttons save time - much easier than shorting pins for firmware updates
Buy 10-20% extra diodes and resistors - you will make mistakes

controllers.title: Controllers
controllers.description: The microcontroller is the most important component in your build - it runs the firmware, processes keypresses, and manages all features. Your choice determines everything from available pins to wireless capability.
whyItMatters: Determines which firmware you can use (QMK, ZMK, etc.)
Sets the limit on how many keys and features you can support
Affects wireless capability and battery life
Influences USB connector type and durability

keyTradeoffs.description: Cheaper controllers (Pro Micro ~$5) work great for basic builds, but lack USB-C and have fewer pins. Premium options (nice!nano ~$30) offer wireless and more flexibility.
More pins = support for larger key matrices and more features. A 60-key split with trackball needs more pins than a 36-key minimal build.
Wireless controllers cost more, require battery management, and work with fewer firmware options (mainly ZMK). Wired is simpler and cheaper.

quickTips: For first builds, Pro Micro or Elite-C are safe, well-documented choices
Planning wireless? Start with nice!nano and ZMK firmware
Count your needed pins: (rows × cols for matrix) + features (OLED, encoders, etc.)
RP2040 boards offer great value with modern features and KMK support

switches.title: Switches
switches.tagline: The heart of your typing experience
switches.description: Switches are the mechanical actuators under each key. They define how your keyboard feels and sounds. This is the most personal choice in your build - what feels perfect to one person might feel awful to another.
whyItMatters: Determines the tactile feel (linear, tactile, clicky)
Affects keyboard height and portability
Limits your keycap options significantly
Influences soldering difficulty and rework options

keyTradeoffs.description: MX switches are standard height (18.5mm) with huge keycap selection. Choc switches are low-profile (11.5mm), lighter, more portable, but keycaps are limited and expensive.
Linear (smooth, no bump), Tactile (bump feedback), or Clicky (bump + sound). There's no 'best' - try before you buy if possible.
MX switches: $0.35-0.70 each. Choc switches: $0.60-1.00 each. For a 60-key board, that's $21-60 just for switches.

quickTips: MX switches are the safe choice for beginners - huge community support
Choc v1 is great for ultra-portable builds but plan for limited keycap options
Buy 10% extra switches for mistakes and future repairs
Consider hotswap sockets to try different switches without resoldering

features.title: Features
features.description: Features are optional enhancements that add functionality beyond basic typing. Each adds complexity, cost, and requires additional pins on your controller. Choose features that match your actual workflow, not just what looks cool.
whyItMatters: Each feature adds to build complexity and time
More features = more pins needed = limits controller choices
Some features (RGB, wireless) significantly increase power consumption
Features can fail independently, making troubleshooting harder

keyTradeoffs.description: Hot-swap sockets let you swap switches without soldering (+$18 for 60 keys). Great for experimenting, but adds height and complexity. Soldered is permanent but slimmer.
Per-key RGB looks amazing but adds significant cost ($15+), complexity, and power draw. Wireless builds should avoid it. Consider if you actually want it or just like the idea.
OLED screens are fun and useful for layer indicators (~$8 for two). Low power draw, but require I2C pins and firmware configuration.

quickTips: Start minimal - you can always build a second keyboard with more features
Trackballs are advanced - expect 8+ hours extra build time
Every feature needs firmware configuration, not just hardware
Calculate total pin requirements before choosing controller

connectivity.title: Connectivity
connectivity.description: Split keyboards need a way for the left and right halves to talk to each other and to your computer. This choice affects convenience, cable management, portability, and power requirements.
whyItMatters: Determines desk cable management complexity
Affects portability and battery requirements
Influences firmware choice (ZMK for wireless, QMK/Vial for wired)
Impacts total cost and build complexity

keyTradeoffs.description: TRRS cable connects both halves (~$5 total cost). Simple, reliable, no batteries, works with QMK/Vial. Downside: cables on your desk, less portable.
Wireless gives ultimate flexibility and clean desk. But: expensive controllers ($60+ for both halves), requires batteries, limited to ZMK firmware, more complex troubleshooting.
Wireless needs LiPo batteries, charging circuits, power switches. Wired just plugs in. Battery life varies: 2 weeks to 6 months depending on features.

quickTips: First build? Go wired with TRRS - it's simple and well-documented
Wireless adds $50+ to controller costs alone
Wireless + RGB = terrible battery life (avoid this combo)
ZMK has excellent wireless support but different workflow than QMK

electronics.title: Electronics & Wiring
electronics.tagline: The nervous system of your keyboard
electronics.description: Hand-wired builds require careful selection of wire, diodes, and connectors. Even PCB builds may need cables for split halves, LEDs, or additional features. Quality electronics ensure reliable connections and easier troubleshooting.
whyItMatters: Wire gauge affects flexibility, current capacity, and ease of soldering
Diode type impacts keypress reliability and troubleshooting difficulty
Proper connectors prevent intermittent failures between split halves
Good solder makes joints stronger and prevents cold joints that fail over time

keyTradeoffs.description: Stranded is flexible but harder to strip/tin. Solid-core is rigid but perfect for point-to-point. Use stranded for movement areas, solid for fixed connections.
Through-hole is beginner-friendly but takes more space. SMD is compact but requires precision soldering. Pre-soldered strips save time but limit flexibility.
Leaded (63/37) melts easier and creates shiny joints. Lead-free is safer but requires higher temps and more skill. Consider ventilation either way.

quickTips: Buy 2x the diodes you need - they're cheap and easy to lose
Use different wire colors for rows vs columns to simplify debugging
Pre-tin wire ends before soldering for stronger connections
Test TRRS cables with a multimeter before final assembly
Keep heat shrink on hand for covering exposed solder joints

firmware.title: Firmware
firmware.tagline: The software that makes it all work
firmware.description: Firmware is the code that runs on your keyboard's controller. It interprets key presses, handles layers, macros, and special features. Your firmware choice affects how you configure your keyboard and what features are available.
whyItMatters: Determines how you configure and customize your keyboard
Some firmware requires coding, others use GUIs
Not all firmware works with all controllers
Affects update frequency and community support

keyTradeoffs.description: QMK is the most popular, feature-rich firmware. Requires compiling code for changes, but incredibly flexible. Huge community, extensive docs. No wireless support.
Vial is QMK with a real-time GUI configurator - no compiling needed. Perfect for beginners. Change keymaps instantly. Same hardware as QMK. No wireless.
ZMK is built for wireless keyboards. Excellent battery life, GitHub-based config. Smaller feature set than QMK, but growing fast. Only choice for nice!nano.
KMK runs CircuitPython on RP2040 boards. Edit code directly on the board like a USB drive. Great for learning. Less optimized than compiled options.

quickTips: Vial is the best beginner choice - instant feedback, no compiling
QMK has the most features and community resources
Going wireless? ZMK is your only real option
You can switch firmware later, but it requires reflashing
